issues.title: PRD: Ticket Deflection Service (Run 04 — C#/.NET 8)
issues.body:
# PRD: Ticket Deflection Service ## Overview Build a Ticket Deflection Service — an ASP.NET Core 8 API that accepts support tickets, classifies them by category and severity, matches them against a knowledge base, and auto-resolves or escalates. A live Razor Pages dashboard shows pipeline metrics, a ticket feed, and an activity log. A simulation endpoint generates realistic demo data on demand. This is the fourth project for the agentic pipeline (prd-to-prod) and the first using C# / .NET. It proves the pipeline is stack-agnostic beyond TypeScript. Deployable to Azure App Service. Dashboard accessible via browser with no setup required. ## Tech Stack - **Runtime**: .NET 8 / ASP.NET Core 8 - **Language**: C# 12 - **API Style**: Minimal API endpoints (REST/JSON) - **Dashboard**: Razor Pages with Tailwind CSS (CDN) and Chart.js (CDN) — served from the same project - **Data**: Entity Framework Core 8 with InMemory provider (no external database) - **Testing**: xUnit + Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing (integration tests via `WebApplicationFactory`) - **NuGet Packages**: `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.InMemory`, `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing`, `Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk`, `xunit`, `xunit.runner.visualstudio` - **Project Template**: `dotnet new web` (ASP.NET Core Empty) - **Solution Structure**: Single solution `TicketDeflection.sln` with two projects — `TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj` (web app) and `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj` (test project) ## Validation Commands - Restore: `dotnet restore TicketDeflection.sln` - Build: `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln --no-restore -warnaserror` - Test: `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln --no-build` - Run: `dotnet run --project TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj --urls http://localhost:5000` ## Features ### Feature 1: Scaffold ASP.NET Core 8 Project Set up the solution structure using `dotnet new web` and `dotnet new xunit`. Configure `Program.cs` with Minimal API routing, Razor Pages, and a health-check endpoint. The project scaffold establishes the folder structure and comment markers that all subsequent features build on. **Technical Notes:** - Run: `dotnet new sln -n TicketDeflection`, `dotnet new web -n TicketDeflection`, `dotnet new xunit -n TicketDeflection.Tests` - `Program.cs` must include `builder.Services.AddRazorPages()` and `app.MapRazorPages()` - `Program.cs` must include two comment markers for later features to insert code: `// --- Service Registrations ---` (after `var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args);`) and `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` (after `var app = builder.Build();`) - Create empty directories: `Models/`, `Services/`, `DTOs/`, `Endpoints/`, `Data/`, `Pages/`, `wwwroot/js/`, `wwwroot/css/` - Do NOT create `Views/` or `Controllers/` — this project uses Minimal APIs + Razor Pages, not MVC - Test project must reference the web project and include a `WebApplicationFactory` test that hits `/health` - Add `` to the web project's `.csproj` so tests can access `Program` **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection.sln` exists at repo root with both projects referenced - [ ] `TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj` targets `net8.0` with `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.InMemory` NuGet package - [ ] `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj` targets `net8.0` with `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing`, `Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk`, `xunit`, `xunit.runner.visualstudio` NuGet packages and a `` to the web project - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Program.cs` contains `AddRazorPages()`, `MapRazorPages()`, the two comment markers (`// --- Service Registrations ---` and `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---`), and maps `GET /health` returning `{ "status": "healthy", "version": "1.0.0" }` with 200 - [ ] Empty directories exist: `Models/`, `Services/`, `DTOs/`, `Endpoints/`, `Data/`, `Pages/`, `wwwroot/js/`, `wwwroot/css/` (each with a `.gitkeep` file) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/appsettings.json` exists with default configuration - [ ] `.gitignore` includes `bin/`, `obj/`, `*.user`, `.vs/` - [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` exits with code 0 and zero warnings - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — at least one test hits `GET /health` via `WebApplicationFactory` and asserts 200 status code ### Feature 2: Ticket Data Model & EF Core InMemory Store Define all entity models, enums, and the EF Core DbContext. This feature creates every data type used by the application so that subsequent features never need to define new entities. **Technical Notes:** - `TicketDbContext` must be registered in DI with InMemory provider: `builder.Services.AddDbContext(o => o.UseInMemoryDatabase("TicketDb"));` - Each test should use a unique in-memory DB name (`Guid.NewGuid().ToString()`) for isolation - All entities use `Guid` for primary keys, auto-generated - `ActivityLog` entity is essential — it will be consumed by the pipeline orchestrator (Feature 7) and the activity log page (Feature 10) **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/Enums.cs` defines enums: `TicketCategory` (Bug, FeatureRequest, HowTo, AccountIssue, Other), `TicketSeverity` (Low, Medium, High, Critical), `TicketStatus` (New, Classified, Matched, AutoResolved, Escalated) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/Ticket.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `Title` (string), `Description` (string), `Category` (TicketCategory), `Severity` (TicketSeverity), `Status` (TicketStatus), `Resolution` (string?, nullable), `Source` (string), `CreatedAt` (DateTime), `UpdatedAt` (DateTime) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/KnowledgeArticle.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `Title` (string), `Content` (string), `Tags` (string, comma-separated), `Category` (TicketCategory) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/ActivityLog.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `TicketId` (Guid), `Action` (string), `Details` (string), `Timestamp` (DateTime) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Data/TicketDbContext.cs` defines `DbContext` with `DbSet`, `DbSet`, `DbSet` - [ ] `TicketDbContext` is registered in `Program.cs` DI container using `UseInMemoryDatabase("TicketDb")` (inserted below the `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker) - [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` exits with code 0 - [ ] At least one test creates a `TicketDbContext` with a unique in-memory DB name, persists a `Ticket` entity, retrieves it, and asserts all fields match ### Feature 3: Ticket CRUD API Endpoints Implement five Minimal API endpoints for managing tickets. These are plain CRUD operations — `POST /api/tickets` creates a ticket with status `New` and does NOT auto-classify or trigger any pipeline logic. **Technical Notes:** - Use DTOs for request/response — never expose the `Ticket` entity directly - `POST /api/tickets` sets `Status = TicketStatus.New` and `CreatedAt = DateTime.UtcNow`. It does NOT call any classification service. - Map endpoints using an extension method in `Endpoints/TicketEndpoints.cs` with `app.MapGroup("/api/tickets")` **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/DTOs/TicketDtos.cs` defines `CreateTicketRequest` (Title, Description, Source), `UpdateTicketRequest` (Title, Description), and `TicketResponse` (all ticket fields) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/TicketEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapTicketEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` (inserted below `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` marker) - [ ] `POST /api/tickets` creates a ticket with `Status = New`, returns 201 with Location header - [ ] `GET /api/tickets` returns 200 with a list of tickets, supports optional `?status=New&category=Bug` query parameter filtering - [ ] `GET /api/tickets/{id}` returns 200 with ticket or 404 if not found - [ ] `PUT /api/tickets/{id}` updates Title/Description, sets `UpdatedAt`, returns 200 or 404 - [ ] `DELETE /api/tickets/{id}` returns 204 or 404 - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — integration tests via `WebApplicationFactory` verify all five endpoints with correct status codes ### Feature 4: Ticket Classification Service Create a standalone classification service that analyzes ticket text and assigns category and severity using keyword rules. Expose a single endpoint to classify an existing ticket. This service does NOT auto-trigger on ticket creation — it is a pure, independently callable service. **Technical Notes:** - Register `ClassificationService` in DI as a scoped service - Keyword matching should be case-insensitive against both title and description - If no keywords match, default to `Category = Other`, `Severity = Medium` **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/ClassificationService.cs` defines a class with method `ClassifyTicket(Ticket ticket)` that sets `ticket.Category` and `ticket.Severity` based on keyword rules, and sets `ticket.Status = TicketStatus.Classified` - [ ] At least 15 keyword-to-category mapping rules defined: e.g. "crash", "error", "broken", "bug", "exception" → Bug; "how do I", "how to", "help with", "guide" → HowTo; "add feature", "request", "wish", "would be nice" → FeatureRequest; "login", "password", "account", "billing", "subscription" → AccountIssue - [ ] Severity rules: Bug keywords default to High; HowTo to Low; FeatureRequest to Medium; AccountIssue to Medium; no-match defaults to Other/Medium - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/ClassifyEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapClassifyEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` - [ ] `POST /api/tickets/{id}/classify` looks up the ticket by ID, runs classification, saves changes, returns 200 with updated ticket or 404 if not found - [ ] `ClassificationService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` (inserted below `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker) - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify that a ticket with "crash" in the title is classified as Bug/High, a ticket with "how do I" is classified as HowTo/Low, and a ticket with no matching keywords is classified as Other/Medium ### Feature 5: Knowledge Base CRUD & Seed Data Implement CRUD endpoints for knowledge articles and seed the database with 12+ articles on startup. This provides the knowledge base that the matching service (Feature 6) will search against. **Technical Notes:** - Seed data is loaded via a static method called during app startup, not via EF Core migrations - The seed method should check if articles already exist before inserting (idempotent) - Map endpoints using `app.MapGroup("/api/knowledge")` **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/DTOs/KnowledgeDtos.cs` defines `CreateKnowledgeRequest` (Title, Content, Tags, Category) and `KnowledgeResponse` (all fields) - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/KnowledgeEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapKnowledgeEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` - [ ] `POST /api/knowledge` creates an article, returns 201 - [ ] `GET /api/knowledge` returns 200 with all articles, supports optional `?category=Bug` filtering - [ ] `GET /api/knowledge/{id}` returns 200 or 404 - [ ] `DELETE /api/knowledge/{id}` returns 204 or 404 - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Data/SeedData.cs` defines a static `Initialize(TicketDbContext context)` method that seeds 12+ articles covering all five `TicketCategory` values: at least 2 Bug articles (e.g. "Common Error Codes", "Crash Recovery Guide"), 2 HowTo articles (e.g. "How to Export Data", "Getting Started Guide"), 2 FeatureRequest articles, 2 AccountIssue articles (e.g. "Password Reset Guide", "Billing FAQ"), 2 Other articles - [ ] `SeedData.Initialize` is called in `Program.cs` after `app.Build()` using a scoped `TicketDbContext` - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify seed data is loaded (article count >= 12) and articles exist for all categories ### Feature 6: Knowledge Base Matching & Resolution Service Create a standalone matching service that takes a classified ticket, searches the knowledge base for relevant articles, and determines whether to auto-resolve or escalate. Expose a single endpoint to resolve an existing ticket. This service does NOT auto-trigger after classification — it is a pure, independently callable service. **Technical Notes:** - Match scoring: compute keyword overlap between ticket (title + description, split on whitespace) and article (content + tags, split on whitespace/commas). Score = intersection count / union count (Jaccard similarity). Both sides lowercased. - Configurable threshold via `appsettings.json` under key `MatchingThreshold` (default: 0.3) - If score >= threshold: set `Status = AutoResolved`, populate `Resolution` with matched article title and snippet - If score < threshold for all articles: set `Status = Escalated` **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/MatchingService.cs` defines a class with method `ResolveTicket(Ticket ticket, TicketDbContext context)` that searches all `KnowledgeArticle` records, computes match scores, and sets ticket status to `AutoResolved` (with resolution text) or `Escalated` - [ ] Match threshold is read from `IConfiguration["MatchingThreshold"]` with default 0.3 - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/ResolveEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapResolveEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` - [ ] `POST /api/tickets/{id}/resolve` looks up the ticket by ID, runs matching, saves changes, returns 200 with JSON containing the updated ticket, matched article(s), and confidence scores — or 404 if ticket not found - [ ] `MatchingService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` (inserted below `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker) - [ ] `appsettings.json` includes `"MatchingThreshold": 0.3` - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify: (1) a ticket about "password reset" matched against seed data scores above threshold and is auto-resolved, (2) a ticket with gibberish description scores below threshold and is escalated ### Feature 7: Ticket Pipeline Orchestrator Create a pipeline service that chains the full lifecycle: create ticket → classify → match → resolve/escalate. This is the single owner of the complete pipeline chain. It calls `ClassificationService` and `MatchingService` internally and writes `ActivityLog` entries at each stage. `POST /api/tickets/submit` is the primary integration endpoint. **Technical Notes:** - `PipelineService` depends on `ClassificationService`, `MatchingService`, and `TicketDbContext` via constructor injection - Writes `ActivityLog` entries: "Ticket Created", "Ticket Classified as {Category}/{Severity}", "Ticket Matched (score: {score})" or "Ticket Escalated (no match above threshold)", "Ticket Auto-Resolved: {article title}" or "Ticket Escalated: no matching articles" - This is the ONLY place that chains classify → match. Features 3, 4, 6 are independently callable. **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/PipelineService.cs` defines a class with method `ProcessTicket(string title, string description, string source, TicketDbContext context)` that: (1) creates a new `Ticket` with `Status = New`, (2) calls `ClassificationService.ClassifyTicket`, (3) calls `MatchingService.ResolveTicket`, (4) writes `ActivityLog` entries for each stage, (5) saves all changes, (6) returns the final ticket and processing results - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/PipelineEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapPipelineEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` - [ ] `POST /api/tickets/submit` accepts `{ "title": "...", "description": "...", "source": "..." }`, runs the full pipeline, returns 200 with JSON containing the final ticket state, classification details, match results (article title, score), and list of activity log entries - [ ] Pipeline handles edge cases: empty description (still classifies as Other/Medium), no knowledge matches (escalates) - [ ] `PipelineService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` (inserted below `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker) - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify: (1) submitting a ticket about "password reset" results in `AutoResolved` status with activity log entries, (2) submitting a ticket with gibberish results in `Escalated` status, (3) activity log contains at least 3 entries per processed ticket ### Feature 8: Dashboard — Overview Page with Metrics API Create the main dashboard Razor Page at `/dashboard` with overview metrics and charts. Data is fetched from a dedicated metrics API endpoint. Charts use Chart.js from CDN and the page uses Tailwind CSS from CDN. **Technical Notes:** - Razor Page files go in `TicketDeflection/Pages/Dashboard.cshtml` and `Dashboard.cshtml.cs` - Do NOT create `Views/` or `Controllers/` — this is a Razor Pages project, not MVC - All chart containers should use `` elements with specific IDs so they are structurally verifiable - Load Chart.js and Tailwind CSS via CDN `` and `` (or Tailwind CDN link) - [ ] Dashboard page contains `` and `` elements for Chart.js - [ ] Dashboard page contains a `
` element for the resolution rate display - [ ] Dashboard page includes a `` - [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — existing metrics endpoint tests still pass ### Feature 10: Dashboard — Activity Log Page Create a separate Razor Page at `/activity` showing a chronological timeline of all pipeline activity log entries. Add a paginated API endpoint for activity data. **Technical Notes:** - Razor Page files go in `TicketDeflection/Pages/Activity.cshtml` and `Activity.cshtml.cs` - Extend the existing `MetricsEndpoints.cs` to add the activity endpoint (same file, same extension method) - Timeline is rendered client-side via JavaScript fetching the activity API **Acceptance Criteria:** - [ ] `GET /api/metrics/activity` is added to `MetricsEndpoints.cs`, returns 200 with JSON array of activity log entries sorted by `Timestamp` descending, supports `?limit=50&offset=0` query parameters for pagination - [ ] `TicketDeflection/Pages/Activity.cshtml` exists (NOT `Views/Activity.cshtml`) with `@page "/activity"` directive - [ ] Activity page includes `` (or Tailwind CDN link) - [ ] Activity page contains a `
` container element - [ ] Activity page includes a `` (or Tailwind CDN link) - [ ] Landing page contains an `

issues.body:
## Description
Set up the solution and project structure for the Ticket Deflection Service using `dotnet new web` and `dotnet new xunit`. Configure `Program.cs` with Minimal API routing, Razor Pages, EF Core InMemory package reference, and a health-check endpoint. This scaffold establishes the folder layout and comment markers that all subsequent features build on.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection.sln` exists at repo root with both `TicketDeflection` and `TicketDeflection.Tests` projects referenced
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj` targets `net8.0`, has `(Nullable)enable(/Nullable)`, and references `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.InMemory` NuGet package
- [ ] `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj` targets `net8.0` with `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing`, `Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk`, `xunit`, `xunit.runner.visualstudio` NuGet packages and a `(ProjectReference)` to the web project
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Program.cs` contains `builder.Services.AddRazorPages()`, `app.MapRazorPages()`, the markers `// --- Service Registrations ---` and `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---`, and maps `GET /health` returning `{ "status": "healthy", "version": "1.0.0" }` with HTTP 200
- [ ] `(InternalsVisibleTo Include="TicketDeflection.Tests" /)` is added to the web project's `.csproj`
- [ ] Empty directories exist with `.gitkeep` files: `TicketDeflection/Models/`, `TicketDeflection/Services/`, `TicketDeflection/DTOs/`, `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/`, `TicketDeflection/Data/`, `TicketDeflection/Pages/`, `TicketDeflection/wwwroot/js/`, `TicketDeflection/wwwroot/css/`
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/appsettings.json` exists with default ASP.NET Core configuration
- [ ] `.gitignore` includes `bin/`, `obj/`, `*.user`, `.vs/`

## Dependencies

## Technical Notes
- Commands to scaffold: `dotnet new sln -n TicketDeflection`, `dotnet new web -n TicketDeflection -o TicketDeflection`, `dotnet new xunit -n TicketDeflection.Tests -o TicketDeflection.Tests`

issues.title: [Pipeline] Ticket Data Model & EF Core InMemory DbContext
issues.body:
## Description
Define all entity models, enums, and the EF Core `TicketDbContext`. This feature creates every data type used by the application so that subsequent features never need to define new entities.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/Enums.cs` defines: `TicketCategory` (Bug, FeatureRequest, HowTo, AccountIssue, Other), `TicketSeverity` (Low, Medium, High, Critical), `TicketStatus` (New, Classified, Matched, AutoResolved, Escalated)
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/Ticket.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `Title` (string), `Description` (string), `Category` (TicketCategory), `Severity` (TicketSeverity), `Status` (TicketStatus), `Resolution` (string?, nullable), `Source` (string), `CreatedAt` (DateTime), `UpdatedAt` (DateTime)
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/KnowledgeArticle.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `Title` (string), `Content` (string), `Tags` (string, comma-separated), `Category` (TicketCategory)
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Models/ActivityLog.cs` defines entity with properties: `Id` (Guid), `TicketId` (Guid), `Action` (string), `Details` (string), `Timestamp` (DateTime)
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Data/TicketDbContext.cs` defines `DbContext` with `DbSet(Ticket)`, `DbSet(KnowledgeArticle)`, `DbSet(ActivityLog)`
- [ ] `TicketDbContext` is registered in `Program.cs` using `UseInMemoryDatabase("TicketDb")` inserted below the `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` exits with code 0
- [ ] At least one test creates a `TicketDbContext` with a unique in-memory DB name (`Guid.NewGuid().ToString()`), persists a `Ticket` entity, retrieves it, and asserts all fields match

## Dependencies
Depends on #125

## Technical Notes
- All entities use `Guid` for primary keys, auto-generated with `Guid.NewGuid()`
- Register DbContext: `builder.Services.AddDbContext(TicketDbContext)(o => o.UseInMemoryDatabase("TicketDb"));`
- Each test should use a unique in-memory DB name for test isolation: `new DbContextOptionsBuilder(TicketDbContext)().UseInMemoryDatabase(Guid.NewGuid().ToString()).Options`
- `ActivityLog` entity is critical — it will be consumed by the pipeline orchestrator (Feature 7) and the activity log page (Feature 10)
- Use C# nullable reference types (`enable`) in all model files

issues.title: [Pipeline] Ticket CRUD Minimal API Endpoints
issues.body:
## Description
Implement five Minimal API endpoints for managing tickets. These are plain CRUD operations — `POST /api/tickets` creates a ticket with status `New` and does NOT trigger any pipeline logic or classification.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/DTOs/TicketDtos.cs` defines `CreateTicketRequest` (Title, Description, Source), `UpdateTicketRequest` (Title, Description), and `TicketResponse` (all ticket fields — never exposes the EF Core entity directly)
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/TicketEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapTicketEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` below the `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` marker
- [ ] Endpoints use `app.MapGroup("/api/tickets")`
- [ ] `POST /api/tickets` creates a ticket with `Status = New`, `CreatedAt = DateTime.UtcNow`, returns 201 with `Location` header pointing to the new resource
- [ ] `GET /api/tickets` returns 200 with a list of `TicketResponse`, supports optional `?status=New&category=Bug` query parameter filtering
- [ ] `GET /api/tickets/{id}` returns 200 with `TicketResponse` or 404 if not found
- [ ] `PUT /api/tickets/{id}` updates Title/Description, sets `UpdatedAt = DateTime.UtcNow`, returns 200 or 404
- [ ] `DELETE /api/tickets/{id}` returns 204 or 404
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — integration tests via `WebApplicationFactory` verify all five endpoints with correct HTTP status codes

## Dependencies
Depends on #126

## Technical Notes
- Use DTOs for all request/response — never expose the `Ticket` entity directly
- Map endpoints as a static extension method in `Endpoints/TicketEndpoints.cs`
- `POST /api/tickets` must NOT call any classification service — it only sets `Status = New`
- Use `TypedResults` for strongly-typed Minimal API responses where possible
- Validation commands: `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln --no-build`

issues.title: [Pipeline] Ticket Classification Service & Classify Endpoint
issues.body:
## Description
Create a standalone classification service that analyzes ticket text and assigns category and severity using keyword rules. Expose a single endpoint to classify an existing ticket. This service does NOT auto-trigger on ticket creation — it is a pure, independently callable service.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/ClassificationService.cs` defines a class with method `ClassifyTicket(Ticket ticket)` that sets `ticket.Category` and `ticket.Severity` based on keyword rules, and sets `ticket.Status = TicketStatus.Classified`
- [ ] At least 15 keyword-to-category mapping rules defined (case-insensitive, matched against both title and description):
  - "crash", "error", "broken", "bug", "exception" → Bug
  - "how do I", "how to", "help with", "guide" → HowTo
  - "add feature", "request", "wish", "would be nice" → FeatureRequest
  - "login", "password", "account", "billing", "subscription" → AccountIssue
- [ ] Severity rules: Bug → High; HowTo → Low; FeatureRequest → Medium; AccountIssue → Medium; no-match → Other/Medium
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/ClassifyEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapClassifyEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` below the `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` marker
- [ ] `POST /api/tickets/{id}/classify` looks up ticket by ID, runs classification, saves changes to DB, returns 200 with updated ticket as `TicketResponse` or 404 if not found
- [ ] `ClassificationService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` as scoped, below the `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify: a ticket with "crash" in title is classified as Bug/High; a ticket with "how do I" is classified as HowTo/Low; a ticket with no matching keywords is classified as Other/Medium

## Dependencies
Depends on #126

## Technical Notes
- Register as scoped: `builder.Services.AddScoped(ClassificationService)();`
- Keyword matching must be case-insensitive using `StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase`
- If no keywords match any category, default to `Category = Other`, `Severity = Medium`
- The `ClassifyTicket` method modifies the ticket object in-place (caller is responsible for saving changes)
Related to #126

issues.title: [Pipeline] Knowledge Base Matching & Resolution Service
issues.body:
## Description
Create a standalone matching service that takes a classified ticket, searches the knowledge base for relevant articles using Jaccard similarity, and determines whether to auto-resolve or escalate. Expose a single endpoint to resolve an existing ticket. This service does NOT auto-trigger after classification — it is a pure, independently callable service.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/MatchingService.cs` defines a class with method `ResolveTicket(Ticket ticket, TicketDbContext context)` that: searches all `KnowledgeArticle` records, computes Jaccard similarity scores, and sets `ticket.Status = AutoResolved` (with `ticket.Resolution` = matched article title + snippet) or `ticket.Status = Escalated`
- [ ] Jaccard similarity: tokenize ticket (title + description) and article (content + tags) by splitting on whitespace/commas, lowercase both, compute `|intersection| / |union|`
- [ ] Match threshold read from `IConfiguration["MatchingThreshold"]` with default `0.3`
- [ ] `appsettings.json` includes `"MatchingThreshold": 0.3`
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/ResolveEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapResolveEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` below the `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` marker
- [ ] `POST /api/tickets/{id}/resolve` looks up ticket by ID, runs matching against all knowledge articles, saves changes, returns 200 with JSON containing the updated ticket, matched article(s), and confidence scores — or 404 if not found
- [ ] `MatchingService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` as scoped, below the `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify: (1) a ticket about "password reset" matched against seed data scores above threshold and results in `AutoResolved` status; (2) a ticket with gibberish description scores below threshold and results in `Escalated` status

## Dependencies
Depends on #137, #128

## Technical Notes
- Register as scoped: `builder.Services.AddScoped(MatchingService)();`
- Jaccard formula: `score = intersection.Count / (double)union.Count`
- If score >= threshold for at least one article: set `Status = AutoResolved`, populate `Resolution` with best match article title
- If no article meets threshold: set `Status = Escalated`
- The `ResolveTicket` method takes the `TicketDbContext` as a parameter (caller is responsible for saving changes)

issues.title: [Pipeline] Ticket Pipeline Orchestrator & Submit Endpoint
issues.body:
## Description
Create a pipeline orchestration service that chains the full ticket lifecycle: create → classify → match → resolve/escalate. This is the single owner of the complete pipeline chain. It calls `ClassificationService` and `MatchingService` internally and writes `ActivityLog` entries at each stage. `POST /api/tickets/submit` is the primary integration endpoint.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Services/PipelineService.cs` defines a class with method `ProcessTicket(string title, string description, string source, TicketDbContext context)` that: (1) creates a new `Ticket` with `Status = New`; (2) calls `ClassificationService.ClassifyTicket`; (3) calls `MatchingService.ResolveTicket`; (4) writes `ActivityLog` entries for each stage; (5) saves all changes; (6) returns the final ticket and processing results
- [ ] Activity log entries written: "Ticket Created", "Ticket Classified as {Category}/{Severity}", "Ticket Matched (score: {score})" or "Ticket Escalated (no match above threshold)", "Ticket Auto-Resolved: {article title}" or "Ticket Escalated: no matching articles"
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/PipelineEndpoints.cs` defines a static `MapPipelineEndpoints(this WebApplication app)` extension method registered in `Program.cs` below the `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---` marker
- [ ] `POST /api/tickets/submit` accepts `{ "title": "...", "description": "...", "source": "..." }`, runs full pipeline, returns 200 with JSON containing: final ticket state, classification details, match results (article title, score), and list of activity log entries
- [ ] Pipeline handles edge cases: empty description (classifies as Other/Medium), no knowledge matches (escalates)
- [ ] `PipelineService` is registered in DI in `Program.cs` as scoped, below the `// --- Service Registrations ---` marker
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — tests verify: (1) submitting a ticket about "password reset" results in `AutoResolved` status with activity log entries; (2) submitting gibberish results in `Escalated` status; (3) activity log contains at least 3 entries per processed ticket

## Dependencies
Depends on #128, #129

## Technical Notes
- `PipelineService` depends on `ClassificationService` and `MatchingService` via constructor injection
- Register as scoped: `builder.Services.AddScoped(PipelineService)();`
- This is the ONLY place that chains classify → match; Features 3, 4, 6 remain independently callable
- `POST /api/tickets/submit` must be mapped BEFORE the `MapTicketEndpoints` group so it takes priority over `/api/tickets/{id}` wildcard routes
Related to #129

issues.title: [Pipeline] Dockerfile & Production Configuration
issues.body:
## Description
Add a multi-stage Dockerfile for containerized deployment and production-specific configuration. Add a README with project overview and run instructions.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `Dockerfile` at repo root with multi-stage build: first stage uses `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0` to restore, build, and publish; second stage uses `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspnet:8.0` as runtime base
- [ ] Dockerfile copies `.csproj` files first for layer caching, then copies source and publishes with `dotnet publish`
- [ ] Dockerfile includes `EXPOSE 8080` and `ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "TicketDeflection.dll"]`
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/appsettings.Production.json` exists with `"MatchingThreshold": 0.25` and `"Logging": { "LogLevel": { "Default": "Warning" } }`
- [ ] `README.md` at repo root (or `TicketDeflection/README.md`) includes: project title, one-paragraph description, tech stack list, build instructions (`dotnet build`), test instructions (`dotnet test`), run instructions (`dotnet run --project TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj`), Docker build command (`docker build -t ticket-deflection .`), and Docker run command (`docker run -p 8080:8080 ticket-deflection`)
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes — all existing tests continue to pass

## Dependencies
Depends on #135

## Technical Notes
- Do NOT include a GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow — it requires Azure secrets that cannot be verified in the pipeline
- Multi-stage Dockerfile pattern:
  ```dockerfile
  FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0 AS build
  WORKDIR /src
  COPY TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj TicketDeflection/
  COPY TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj TicketDeflection.Tests/
  RUN dotnet restore TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj
  COPY . .
  RUN dotnet publish TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj -c Release -o /app/publish

  FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspnet:8.0 AS runtime
  WORKDIR /app
  COPY --from=build /app/publish .
  EXPOSE 8080
  ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "TicketDeflection.dll"]
  ```
- `appsettings.Production.json` overrides development defaults for a production-ready configuration

- [ ] `GET /api/knowledge/{id}` returns 200 or 404
- [ ] `DELETE /api/knowledge/{id}` returns 204 or 404
- [ ] `TicketDeflection/Data/SeedData.cs` defines a static `Initialize(TicketDbContext context)` method that seeds 12+ articles covering all five `TicketCategory` values: at least 2 Bug articles (e.g. "Common Error Codes", "Crash Recovery Guide"), 2 HowTo articles (e.g. "How to Export Data", "Getting Started Guide"), 2 FeatureRequest articles, 2 AccountIssue articles (e.g. "Password Reset Guide", "Billing FAQ"), 2 Other articles
- [ ] `SeedData.Initialize` is called in `Program.cs` after `app.Build()` using a scoped `TicketDbContext`

## Dependencies
Depends on #126

- Map endpoints using `app.MapGroup("/api/knowledge")`
- Seed method is called in `Program.cs` right after building the app, using a scoped `TicketDbContext`:

  ```csharp
  using (var scope = app.Services.CreateScope())
  {
      var context = scope.ServiceProvider.GetRequiredService<TicketDbContext>();
      SeedData.Initialize(context);
  }
  ```

issues.title: [Pipeline] Add .NET 8 CI workflow for build and test verification
issues.body:
## Description
Add a GitHub Actions CI workflow that runs `dotnet build` and `dotnet test` on every pull request. Without this, the pipeline review agent cannot verify acceptance criteria like "`dotnet build` exits with code 0" or "`dotnet test` passes", causing valid PRs to receive REQUEST_CHANGES for unverifiable criteria.

This is critical infrastructure for Run 04 (C#/.NET 8 project). All 13 feature issues include build/test criteria.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `.github/workflows/dotnet-ci.yml` exists
- [ ] Workflow triggers on `pull_request` targeting `main`
- [ ] Workflow uses `actions/setup-dotnet@v4` with `dotnet-version: '8.0.x'`
- [ ] Workflow runs `dotnet restore TicketDeflection.sln`
- [ ] Workflow runs `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln --no-restore`
- [ ] Workflow runs `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln --no-build` (only if test project exists)
- [ ] Workflow completes successfully on a PR that includes valid .NET code

## Dependencies
None — this is standalone infrastructure. Should be prioritized ahead of feature issues.

## Technical Notes
- Use `ubuntu-latest` runner
- The solution file `TicketDeflection.sln` and projects already exist on main (merged via PR #138 scaffold)
- Keep it simple — no caching, no artifacts, just build + test
- Example structure:
  ```yaml
  name: .NET CI
  on:
    pull_request:
      branches: [main]
  jobs:
    build-and-test:
      runs-on: ubuntu-latest
      steps:
        - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        - uses: actions/setup-dotnet@v4
          with:
            dotnet-version: '8.0.x'
        - run: dotnet restore TicketDeflection.sln
        - run: dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln --no-restore
        - run: dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln --no-build --verbosity normal
  ```

issues.title: [Pipeline] Add .NET 8 CI workflow for build and test verification
issues.body:

Adds `.github/workflows/dotnet-ci.yml` — a GitHub Actions CI workflow that runs on every pull request targeting `main`:

- `dotnet restore TicketDeflection.sln`

- `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln --no-build --verbosity normal`

Uses `ubuntu-latest` runner and `actions/setup-dotnet@v4` with `dotnet-version: '8.0.x'`.

This enables the pipeline review agent to verify build/test acceptance criteria on all subsequent Run 04 PRs.

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix CS0117 build error: KnowledgeArticle missing CreatedAt property
issues.body:
## Problem

`dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` fails with:

```
error CS0117: 'KnowledgeArticle' does not contain a definition for 'CreatedAt'
```

**File**: `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/KnowledgeEndpoints.cs:34`

## Root Cause

`KnowledgeEndpoints.cs` line 34 sets `CreatedAt = DateTime.UtcNow` when creating a new `KnowledgeArticle`, but the `KnowledgeArticle` model class (`TicketDeflection/Models/KnowledgeArticle.cs`) does not have a `CreatedAt` property.

The `Ticket` model has `CreatedAt` and `UpdatedAt` properties, but `KnowledgeArticle` was defined without them.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Add `public DateTime CreatedAt { get; set; } = DateTime.UtcNow;` to `KnowledgeArticle` model in `TicketDeflection/Models/KnowledgeArticle.cs`
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` completes with 0 errors
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes all existing tests
- [ ] No other compilation errors remain

## Context

This is a post-Run-04 build fix. All 13 features were merged but the app doesn't compile due to this integration gap from parallel PRs.

issues.title: [Pipeline] Update target framework from net8.0 to net10.0
issues.body:
## Problem

The project targets `net8.0` but the CI runner and local dev environment have .NET 10 installed. While `global.json` uses `rollForward: latestMajor` (allowing SDK 10 to compile net8.0 code), the **runtime** must match the target framework. This means:

- `dotnet run` fails: "You must install or update .NET to run this application" (no .NET 8 runtime)
- `dotnet test` aborts: test host needs .NET 8 runtime to execute
- Docker build works (uses `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0` image) but targets an older LTS

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Update `TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj` to `<TargetFramework>net10.0</TargetFramework>`
- [ ] Update `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj` to `<TargetFramework>net10.0</TargetFramework>`
- [ ] Update `global.json` SDK version to `10.0.102` with `rollForward: latestPatch`
- [ ] Update `Dockerfile` base images from `dotnet/sdk:8.0` / `dotnet/aspnet:8.0` to `dotnet/sdk:10.0` / `dotnet/aspnet:10.0`
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes all existing tests

**IMPORTANT**: Do NOT modify `.github/workflows/dotnet-ci.yml` — the PAT does not have workflow scope. The CI workflow will be updated separately.

## Context

The project was generated targeting .NET 8 (LTS) but the development and CI environments have .NET 10. Upgrading ensures consistent build/test/run across all environments.

issues.body:
## Problem

PR #182 upgraded the target framework to `net10.0` but left NuGet packages at .NET 8 versions. This causes 33 of 62 tests to fail with `InternalServerError` — the .NET 8 EF Core and ASP.NET Core packages are incompatible with the .NET 10 runtime.

Build succeeds (0 errors) but tests fail at runtime.

### Current package versions (wrong)

**TicketDeflection.csproj:**
- `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.InMemory` 8.0.0

**TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj:**
- `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing` 8.0.0
- `Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk` 17.8.0
- `xunit` 2.5.3
- `xunit.runner.visualstudio` 2.5.3
- `coverlet.collector` 6.0.0

### Build warning
```
warning NU1903: Package 'Microsoft.Extensions.Caching.Memory' 8.0.0 has a known high severity vulnerability
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Update `TicketDeflection/TicketDeflection.csproj`: `Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.InMemory` to latest 10.0.x (or 9.0.x if 10.0 not available yet)
- [ ] Update `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketDeflection.Tests.csproj`: `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing` to latest 10.0.x (or 9.0.x if 10.0 not available yet)

- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes all 62 tests
- [ ] No `NU1903` vulnerability warnings remain

**IMPORTANT**: Do NOT modify any files in `.github/workflows/` — the PAT does not have workflow scope.

Post-Run-04 build fix. Framework upgraded to net10.0 in PR #182, but packages left at .NET 8 versions causing runtime test failures.

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix EF Core in-memory database scoping in test fixtures
issues.body:
## Problem

2 of 62 tests fail after the NuGet upgrade to EF Core 9.0.x:

1. **`PipelineServiceTests.Submit_PasswordReset_AutoResolved_WithActivityLogs`** — expects `"AutoResolved"`, gets `"Escalated"`
2. **`MetricsEndpointTests.GetOverview_AfterSimulation_ReflectsTickets`** — expects `totalTickets = 10`, gets `0`

## Root Cause

In 5 test files, `Guid.NewGuid()` is placed **inside** the EF Core options builder lambda:

```csharp
services.AddDbContext<TicketDbContext>(o =>
    o.UseInMemoryDatabase($"TestDb_{Guid.NewGuid()}"));  // BUG: evaluated per-scope
```

`AddDbContext` registers `DbContextOptions<TContext>` with `ServiceLifetime.Scoped` by default. The options builder lambda is re-invoked for every DI scope (every HTTP request), generating a **different** database name each time. This means:

- The startup seed (knowledge articles) goes into one database, but HTTP request scopes use different databases — so no knowledge articles exist for matching, and all tickets are escalated.
- In `MetricsEndpointTests`, the simulate request saves tickets to one database, but the metrics request queries a different empty database — returning 0 tickets.

## Fix

In each affected test file, capture the Guid **outside** the options lambda so all scopes share the same in-memory database:

```csharp
var dbName = $"TestDb_{Guid.NewGuid()}";  // evaluated once per test class instance
services.AddDbContext<TicketDbContext>(o =>
    o.UseInMemoryDatabase(dbName));
```

## Affected Files

Apply this fix to all 5 test files that use this pattern:

1. `TicketDeflection.Tests/PipelineServiceTests.cs` (line 26)
2. `TicketDeflection.Tests/MetricsEndpointTests.cs` (line 23)
3. `TicketDeflection.Tests/SimulateEndpointTests.cs` (line 23)
4. `TicketDeflection.Tests/TicketFeedEndpointTests.cs` (line 22)
5. `TicketDeflection.Tests/ActivityEndpointTests.cs` (line 24)

**Do NOT change** `MatchingServiceTests.cs` or `TicketDbContextTests.cs` — those use `Guid.NewGuid()` correctly (outside the lambda or in direct `DbContextOptionsBuilder` calls).

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All 5 listed test files updated: `Guid.NewGuid()` captured outside the options lambda
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds with 0 errors/warnings
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes all 62 tests (including the 2 currently failing)
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Auto-seed 25 demo tickets on startup for cold-start dashboard
[Pipeline] Redirect Run Demo button to /dashboard after simulation
[Pipeline] Fix tokenizer to strip punctuation for accurate Jaccard matching
issues.body:
## Problem

The Ticket Deflection Service auto-resolves **0 out of 25 tickets** (0% deflection rate). The entire demo story is broken — the dashboard shows 100% escalation, zero auto-resolution. The app is supposed to demonstrate intelligent ticket deflection against a knowledge base.

## Root Cause

The `Tokenize` method in both `MatchingService.cs` and `PipelineService.cs` splits text on whitespace and commas but **does not strip punctuation** from token boundaries. This causes token mismatches that tank the Jaccard similarity scores below the 0.3 threshold.

Example: The "Password Reset Guide" KB article contains:
```
Click 'Forgot Password' on the login page, enter your email, and follow the reset link sent to your inbox.
```

After tokenization, this produces `'forgot` (with leading apostrophe) and `password'` (with trailing apostrophe) instead of `forgot` and `password`. A ticket containing "I forgot my password" tokenizes to `forgot` and `password` — neither matches the punctuation-polluted article tokens.

Similarly, `inbox.` (trailing period) never matches `inbox`.

This affects ALL 12 knowledge base articles. The scores all fall below 0.3, so every ticket escalates.

## Fix

In **both** tokenizer locations, add a `.Trim()` call to strip common punctuation from token boundaries, and filter out empty tokens:

### File 1: `TicketDeflection/Services/MatchingService.cs` (line 50-53)

Current:
```csharp
private static HashSet<string> Tokenize(string text) =>
    text.Split([' ', '\t', ',', '\n', '\r'], StringSplitOptions.RemoveEmptyEntries)
        .Select(t => t.ToLowerInvariant())
        .ToHashSet();
```

Fixed:
```csharp
private static HashSet<string> Tokenize(string text) =>
    text.Split([' ', '\t', ',', '\n', '\r'], StringSplitOptions.RemoveEmptyEntries)
        .Select(t => t.Trim('\'', '"', '.', '!', '?', '(', ')', ':', ';', '-'))
        .Where(t => t.Length > 0)
        .Select(t => t.ToLowerInvariant())
        .ToHashSet();
```

### File 2: `TicketDeflection/Services/PipelineService.cs` (line 89-92)

Same change — this file has a **duplicate** `Tokenize` method used for logging the match score. Apply the identical fix.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Both `Tokenize` methods (in `MatchingService.cs` and `PipelineService.cs`) strip punctuation from token boundaries
- [ ] `POST /api/simulate?count=25` produces a mix of `AutoResolved` and `Escalated` tickets (not 100% escalated)
- [ ] `GET /api/metrics/overview` shows `autoResolved > 0` and `resolutionRate > 0` after simulation
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds with 0 errors
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` — no regressions
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Improve landing page visual design and demo flow
issues.body:
## Problem

The landing page at `/` is functional but visually underwhelming for a portfolio demo. It reads like a developer test page — plain white card, unstyled buttons, no visual hierarchy beyond font size. When someone clicks this link from LinkedIn, the first impression needs to communicate "this is a production-quality app built autonomously by a pipeline," not "this is a homework assignment."

The demo flow also has a UX gap: after clicking "Run Demo," the user sees raw JSON output and has to manually navigate to `/dashboard` to see results. The simulation should guide the user to the results.

## Desired Outcome

The landing page should feel like a polished SaaS product landing page. Specifically:

- Visual hierarchy that draws the eye from headline → pipeline flow → action button → navigation
- The pipeline flow diagram (Intake → Classify → Match → Resolve/Escalate) should feel like an actual diagram, not a line of text
- Color palette and spacing should feel intentional and professional — consider a gradient or subtle background pattern
- The "Run Demo" button should be the obvious primary CTA with clear visual weight
- Dashboard / Activity Log / Ticket Feed navigation should feel secondary to the CTA but easily discoverable
- After simulation completes, redirect the user to `/dashboard` instead of displaying JSON — the dashboard is the result
- Add a brief stat or tagline that communicates what the demo will show (e.g., ticket count, expected deflection rate)
- Responsive — should look good on both desktop and mobile

## Constraints

- Razor Pages + Tailwind CSS (already in the project — use what's there)
- No new npm packages or frontend frameworks
- Keep the existing API contract — `POST /api/simulate?count=25` stays the same
- The landing page is `Pages/Index.cshtml` with its `Pages/Index.cshtml.cs` page model
- `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` must pass with 0 errors
- `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` — no regressions
- No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: Fix demo deflection rate: tune seed tickets and lower matching threshold for ~70% resolution
issues.body:
## Problem

The landing page advertises **~70% deflection rate** but the dashboard shows **~1.3%** after seeding. This makes the app look broken.

**Root cause:** The 24 sample ticket templates in `SimulateEndpoints.cs` have minimal token overlap with the 12 knowledge base articles in `SeedData.cs`. The Jaccard similarity algorithm needs exact word matches, and the current ticket descriptions use different vocabulary than the KB articles. Combined with a 0.3 threshold, almost every ticket gets escalated.

## Solution

Two changes — a data fix and a threshold tweak:

### 1. Lower matching threshold (one-line change)

**File:** `TicketDeflection/appsettings.json` line 9

Change:
```json
"MatchingThreshold": 0.3
```
To:
```json
"MatchingThreshold": 0.15
```

### 2. Rewrite sample tickets to overlap with KB articles

**File:** `TicketDeflection/Endpoints/SimulateEndpoints.cs` lines 8-39

Replace the entire `SampleTickets` array with tickets that share vocabulary with the 12 KB articles. The goal is **17 out of 24 templates matching** (≈70.8% base rate).

Here are the 12 KB articles and key tokens to target:

| # | KB Article | Key tokens in Content+Tags |
|---|-----------|---------------------------|
| 1 | Common Error Codes | error, 500, internal, server, 404, not, found, 403, forbidden, access |
| 2 | Crash Recovery Guide | application, crashes, restart, service, manager, check, logs, details |
| 3 | How to Export Data | navigate, settings, export, csv, json, format, data |
| 4 | Getting Started Guide | create, account, verify, email, explore, dashboard, help, button, tooltips |
| 5 | How to Configure Notifications | go, profile, notifications, enable, disable, email, in-app, alerts, events |
| 6 | Feature Request Process | submit, feature, requests, feedback, portal, review, quarterly, vote, count |
| 7 | Planned Feature Roadmap | upcoming, features, dark, mode, api, v2, bulk, operations, public, roadmap, timelines |
| 8 | Password Reset Guide | click, forgot, password, login, page, enter, email, reset, link, sent, inbox |
| 9 | Billing FAQ | subscriptions, renew, monthly, cancel, billing, subscription, refunds, available, days, payment |
| 10 | Two-Factor Authentication Setup | enable, 2fa, security, settings, authenticator, app, google, authy |
| 11 | Service Status and Uptime | check, status, page, real-time, information, outages, maintenance, service, uptime |
| 12 | Contact Support | reach, support, team, email, in-app, chat, widget, available, weekdays |

Replace the `SampleTickets` array with exactly this (preserving the existing structure of 5 Bug + 5 HowTo + 5 FeatureRequest + 5 AccountIssue + 4 Other):

```csharp
internal static readonly (string Title, string Description, string Source)[] SampleTickets =
[
    // Bug category (5 templates — 4 match KB articles, 1 miss)
    ("Error 500 on the server", "I keep getting an error 500 internal server error when loading the main page. The error appears on every request to the server.", "web"),
    ("Application crashes after restart", "The application crashes immediately after restart. I checked the logs in the service manager but could not find details about the crash recovery steps.", "api"),
    ("Export button gives no response", "I navigate to settings and click the export button but the CSV format download never starts. Tried JSON format export too.", "email"),
    ("Error 403 forbidden access on the server", "When I try to access the admin panel I get an error 403 forbidden. The server returns a forbidden access error on every request.", "web"),
    ("Search returns wrong results", "When I search for recent orders the results show completely unrelated documents from other users.", "api"),

    // HowTo category (5 templates — 4 match, 1 miss)
    ("How to reset my password", "I forgot my password and clicked the reset link on the login page but the email was never sent to my inbox.", "web"),
    ("How to export my data as CSV", "I need to navigate to settings and export all my data in CSV or JSON format for compliance.", "email"),
    ("How to enable two-factor authentication", "I want to enable 2FA under my security settings using an authenticator app like Google Authenticator or Authy.", "web"),
    ("How to configure notification alerts", "I want to go to my profile notifications and disable email alerts and in-app alerts for non-critical events.", "api"),
    ("How to invite team members", "I want to add three colleagues to my workspace but cannot find the invite option anywhere in settings.", "email"),

    // FeatureRequest category (5 templates — 3 match, 2 miss)
    ("Submit a feature request via feedback", "How do I submit feature requests through the feedback portal? I want my vote to count in the quarterly review process.", "web"),
    ("Dark mode and API v2 on the roadmap", "Are dark mode and API v2 upcoming features on the public roadmap? Would love timelines for bulk operations too.", "api"),
    ("Add Slack integration for alerts", "We use Slack for team communication and would love to get ticket alerts directly in our channels.", "email"),
    ("Add bulk operations to the platform", "Bulk operations for managing multiple items would save time. Is this an upcoming feature on the public roadmap with timelines?", "web"),
    ("Export metrics as PDF report", "Management needs monthly PDF summaries of resolution rates and ticket volumes for executive review.", "api"),

    // AccountIssue category (5 templates — 4 match, 1 miss)
    ("Forgot password and reset email not arriving", "I clicked forgot password on the login page and entered my email but the reset link was never sent to my inbox.", "email"),
    ("Cancel my subscription and get a refund", "I want to cancel my subscription and need a refund. I went to billing but the cancel subscription option is not available within the 7 days window.", "web"),
    ("Two-factor authentication code not working", "The authenticator app code is not accepted. I enabled 2FA under security settings using Google Authenticator but it keeps failing.", "api"),
    ("Account locked after failed logins", "My account was locked after multiple failed login attempts. I need to click forgot password on the login page to get a reset link sent to my email.", "email"),
    ("Billing address not updating", "Every time I save a new billing address the old one reappears and the update never persists.", "web"),

    // Other category (4 templates — 2 match, 2 miss)
    ("Check service status and uptime", "Where can I check the service status page for real-time information about outages and scheduled maintenance windows?", "web"),
    ("Contact the support team", "How do I reach the support team via email or through the in-app chat widget during weekdays?", "email"),
    ("Feedback on the new dashboard UI", "The new dashboard design looks good but the font size in the sidebar feels too small on 1080p monitors.", "api"),
    ("Question about data retention policy", "How long does the system keep closed ticket records before archiving or permanently deleting them?", "web"),
];
```

### Why these tickets work

Each "match" ticket reuses **4-12 exact tokens** from its target KB article's Content+Tags fields. With Jaccard similarity and a 0.15 threshold:
- Matching tickets score 0.19–0.53 against their best KB article
- Non-matching tickets score below 0.10 against all articles
- 17/24 templates match → ~70.8% deflection rate across any random sample of 25

### No other files need changes

The landing page (`Pages/Index.cshtml` line 59) already shows "~70% Expected deflection rate" — after this fix the dashboard's actual computed rate will agree with it.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `MatchingThreshold` in `appsettings.json` is `0.15`
- [ ] All 24 sample ticket templates in `SimulateEndpoints.cs` are replaced with the versions above
- [ ] On app startup, the dashboard (`/dashboard`) shows a resolution rate between 60-80%
- [ ] The resolution rate on the dashboard approximately matches the "~70%" shown on the landing page
- [ ] All existing tests continue to pass

## Labels

bug, pipeline

issues.title: [Pipeline] Redesign landing page with Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic — the pipeline is the star
issues.body:
## Problem

The current landing page has generic AI-generated aesthetics: purple gradients, indigo/violet palette, symmetric 3-column card grids, emoji icons, and cookie-cutter SaaS layout. It tells the wrong story — it presents the ticket deflection service as the product. The real story is that this entire application was built autonomously by an AI pipeline, from PRD to production, with zero human code.

## Story

**Drop a PRD, get a deployed app. Zero human code.**

This page is a showcase for **prd-to-prod** — an autonomous software pipeline powered by **gh-aw** (GitHub Agentic Workflows). It decomposes product requirements into GitHub Issues, implements them as Pull Requests, reviews its own code, merges to main — and self-heals when things break. No human writes a single line of code.

The ticket deflection service you see here? It's just one thing the pipeline made. It's the *proof*, not the *point*. The visitor should think: "I could drop ANY PRD into this and get a deployed app."

**Hierarchy of emphasis:**
1. **Primary (80% of the page)**: The prd-to-prod pipeline powered by gh-aw — what it is, how it works, what makes it different (fully autonomous, self-healing, zero human code)
2. **Secondary (20%)**: The ticket deflection service — a working product the pipeline built, which you can demo live
3. **The link**: The pipeline flow (PRD → 13 issues → 13 PRs → AI review → auto-merge → production) connects the two — it shows HOW the pipeline produced this specific artifact

**Key concepts to surface:**
- **gh-aw agentic workflows** — the engine that powers the pipeline
- **Fully autonomous** — no human in the loop for code, review, or merge
- **Self-healing** — the pipeline detects stalls, retries failures, cleans up superseded PRs
- **Verifiable** — every issue, PR, review, and merge is public on GitHub

## Aesthetic Direction: Blueprint × Terminal

A synthesis of two visual languages:

**Blueprint (the plan)** — The PRD is the blueprint. Engineering drawings, technical schematics, grid-paper texture, precise annotations, architectural precision. The "what we're building" layer.

**Terminal (the execution)** — The pipeline is the terminal. Monospace output, command-line prompts, process status indicators, real-time execution feel. The "how it got built" layer.

**Synthesis principles:**
- Dark background with subtle grid lines (inverted blueprint paper)
- Technical and precise, but alive — processes running, status updating
- The blueprint provides structure and layout; the terminal provides texture and motion
- Data should feel like instrument readings, not marketing cards
- The pipeline flow should feel like a system schematic, not a marketing diagram
- Typography should pair a distinctive display/heading font with a monospace font for data and terminal elements

**Mood references** (for conceptual direction, not to copy): engineering control rooms, architectural blueprints, terminal UIs like htop/lazygit, NASA mission control displays.

## Anti-Slop Rules

These specific patterns MUST be avoided — they are hallmarks of generic AI-generated frontends:

- No indigo/violet/purple gradient backgrounds (the current `#0f172a → #1e1b4b` gradient)
- No Inter, Roboto, Arial, or system default fonts — choose distinctive fonts via Google Fonts CDN
- No symmetric 3-column card grids with identical styling
- No emoji characters as visual elements (📥 🏷️ 🔍 ✅ 📊 etc.)
- No `bg-white/5 border border-white/10` card patterns
- No `rounded-xl` applied uniformly to everything
- No gradient text effects (`bg-clip-text bg-gradient-to-r`)
- No generic "SaaS landing page" layout — this is a technical demo, not a product page
- No loading animations that are just pulsing dots

## Page Structure (Landing Page)

The page should include these content sections (layout and visual treatment are up to you):

1. **Hero**: The headline is about the pipeline, not the service. The core message: "Drop a PRD, get a deployed app. Zero human code." Powered by gh-aw agentic workflows. The visitor should immediately understand they're looking at an autonomous software factory, not a ticket app.

2. **How the Pipeline Works**: The core of the page. Visualize the prd-to-prod pipeline powered by gh-aw agentic workflows — how a PRD gets decomposed into GitHub Issues, how an AI agent writes code for each issue, how another AI reviews each PR, how it auto-merges to production, and how it self-heals when things break. This is the blueprint/schematic centerpiece. It should feel like a system architecture diagram, not a marketing infographic. Name the technology: **gh-aw** (GitHub Agentic Workflows).

3. **The Proof — A Working Product**: Introduce the ticket deflection service as OUTPUT of the pipeline. Frame it as: "Here's a complete C#/.NET application the pipeline built from a single PRD — 13 features, fully tested, production-ready." This is secondary to the pipeline explanation. Include:
   - What the pipeline produced: 13 issues decomposed → 13 PRs merged → working app
   - Live demo trigger: button to run 25 tickets through the service (POST /api/simulate?count=25 → redirect to /dashboard)
   - Present the demo stats (25 tickets, ~70% deflection, <2s processing) as terminal output or instrument readings, not marketing cards

4. **Provenance / Verify It**: Link to the GitHub repo (`samuelkahessay/agentic-pipeline`). Emphasize that this is real and verifiable — every issue, PR, review, and merge is public.

5. **Navigation**: Links to Dashboard (`/dashboard`), Activity Log (`/activity`), Ticket Feed (`/tickets`) — framed as "explore what the pipeline built."

## Functional Requirements (Preserve These Exactly)

- Demo button calls `POST /api/simulate?count=25` and redirects to `/dashboard` on success
- Error state shown if the API call fails (with error message)
- Navigation links to `/dashboard`, `/activity`, `/tickets`
- Page is responsive (works on mobile and desktop)
- Tailwind CSS via CDN (`https://cdn.tailwindcss.com`) — no new dependencies
- Google Fonts CDN is allowed for distinctive typography
- The page is a self-contained Razor Page (no shared _Layout.cshtml needed)
- The `@page "/"` directive and `@model IndexModel` must remain

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Landing page redesigned with cohesive Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic
- [ ] Hero section communicates the prd-to-prod pipeline as the primary subject — the visitor understands they're looking at an autonomous AI factory, not a ticket deflection app
- [ ] Pipeline architecture (PRD → decompose → code → review → merge → production) is visualized as the main content of the page, not a secondary element
- [ ] Ticket deflection service is framed as proof/output of the pipeline, not the product itself
- [ ] None of the anti-slop patterns listed above are present in the final code
- [ ] Typography uses at least one distinctive font loaded via Google Fonts CDN (not Inter/Roboto/Arial/system fonts)
- [ ] Stats presented as instrument readings or terminal output, not marketing cards
- [ ] Demo button works: POST /api/simulate?count=25, redirects to /dashboard on success, shows error on failure
- [ ] All navigation links work (/dashboard, /activity, /tickets)
- [ ] Page is responsive on mobile and desktop
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

## Quality Bar

Two tests this page must pass:

1. **The slop test**: If someone could look at this and say "an AI generated this" — it has failed. The Blueprint×Terminal synthesis should feel like an intentional design decision, not two themes pasted together.

2. **The story test**: After 5 seconds on the page, a visitor should understand that they're looking at an autonomous AI pipeline that builds software, NOT a ticket deflection product. The ticket service is a specimen in the display case — the pipeline is the museum.

issues.title: [Pipeline] Apply Blueprint×Terminal design language to Dashboard, Tickets, and Activity pages

issues.title: [Pipeline] Add Run History section to landing page — showcase all 4 pipeline runs
issues.body:
## Problem

The landing page currently only showcases Run 04 (Ticket Deflection Service) as the pipeline's output. But the pipeline has autonomously built **4 complete applications** across **3 different tech stacks**. Showing only one run undersells the pipeline's capabilities — the visitor doesn't see that this thing is stack-agnostic and has shipped repeatedly.

## Solution

Add a **Run History** section to the landing page (Index.cshtml) that showcases all 4 pipeline runs as a build log / mission manifest. This replaces the current single-specimen framing with a portfolio that demonstrates the pipeline's range and consistency.

Depends on #201

## Content — The Four Runs

Display these runs in reverse chronological order (latest first):

**Run 04 — Ticket Deflection Service** (current, live demo available)
- Stack: C# / .NET 10 / ASP.NET Core / Razor Pages / EF Core
- Stats: 13 issues decomposed → 13 PRs merged
- Note: This is the live instance — link to the demo button or /dashboard
- Status: LIVE / ACTIVE

**Run 03 — DevCard**
- Stack: Next.js 14 / TypeScript / Tailwind CSS / Framer Motion
- Stats: 17 issues → 22 PRs merged, 29 tests, 6 themes
- Tag: [`v3.0.0`](https://github.com/samuelkahessay/prd-to-prod/tree/v3.0.0)
- Description: Developer identity card generator with GitHub profile data, themed cards, and export options

**Run 02 — Pipeline Observatory**
- Stack: Next.js 14 / TypeScript / Tailwind CSS / Framer Motion
- Stats: 12 issues → 19 PRs merged, 32 tests
- Tag: [`v2.0.0`](https://github.com/samuelkahessay/prd-to-prod/tree/v2.0.0)
- Description: Dashboard that visualizes the pipeline itself — interactive simulator, timeline replay, forensic inspection

**Run 01 — Code Snippet Manager**
- Stack: Express / TypeScript / EJS
- Stats: 8 issues → 7 PRs merged
- Tag: [`v1.0.0`](https://github.com/samuelkahessay/prd-to-prod/tree/v1.0.0)
- Description: First end-to-end pipeline test — CRUD app with tagging and full-text search
- Note: This was the first run, with 5 pipeline fixes discovered and resolved during execution

## Design Direction

Follow the Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic established in the landing page redesign (#201). The run history should feel like:

- A **build manifest** or **mission log** — not a portfolio grid or card carousel
- Each run is a log entry with structured data fields (run number, codename, stack, stats, tag link)
- The most recent run (04) should be visually distinguished as ACTIVE/LIVE since it's the one running on this instance
- Older runs should have links to their git tags so visitors can inspect the actual code — git tags are the source of truth, not live deployments
- The cumulative stats are the headline: "4 runs. 4 apps. 3 tech stacks. 50+ issues. 61+ PRs. Zero human code."

Think terminal process table, not marketing cards. Think `docker ps` or `kubectl get pods`, not a SaaS feature comparison grid.

## Placement

Insert the Run History section **between** the current "specimen" section (Ticket Deflection Service details) and the Demo CTA section. The flow should be:

1. Hero (pipeline story)
2. Pipeline schematic (how it works)
3. **Run History (NEW)** — all 4 runs as a build manifest, demonstrating range and consistency
4. The current specimen section can be simplified or merged — Run 04's details are now in the run history, and the demo CTA follows naturally
5. Demo CTA
6. Provenance
7. Navigation

Alternatively, if the run history section makes the specimen section redundant, the agent may merge them — the key data (13 issues, 13 PRs, live demo) should still be present somewhere above the demo button.

## Anti-Slop Rules (same as #201)

- No symmetric card grids with identical styling
- No emoji characters
- No `rounded-xl` uniformly applied
- No gradient text effects
- No generic portfolio/gallery layout — this is a build log, not a showcase grid
- Stats should feel like instrument readings, not marketing metrics

## Functional Requirements

- All git tag links must point to correct URLs: `https://github.com/samuelkahessay/prd-to-prod/tree/v{X}.0.0`
- No live deployment links — git tags and GitHub history are the source of truth
- Existing demo button functionality preserved (POST /api/simulate?count=25 → redirect /dashboard)
- All existing navigation links still work
- Page remains responsive on mobile and desktop
- `@page "/"` directive and `@model IndexModel` must remain
- Tailwind CSS via CDN, Google Fonts CDN — no new dependencies

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Run History section added to landing page showing all 4 pipeline runs
- [ ] Each run displays: run number, app name, tech stack, issue/PR stats, git tag link
- [ ] Run 04 (Ticket Deflection) is visually distinguished as the active/live run
- [ ] Cumulative stats are visible (total runs, total issues, total PRs, tech stacks used)
- [ ] Runs 01-03 link to their respective git tags on GitHub
- [ ] No live deployment links — provenance is through git history, not external URLs
- [ ] Section follows Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic — feels like a build manifest, not a portfolio grid
- [ ] No anti-slop patterns present (no card grids, no emoji, no gradient text)
- [ ] Demo button still works (POST /api/simulate?count=25 → redirect /dashboard)
- [ ] All navigation links work (/dashboard, /activity, /tickets)
- [ ] Page is responsive on mobile and desktop
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix demo button: each press adds 25 tickets instead of resetting to a clean slate
issues.body:
## Bug

Each press of the "Run Demo" button on the landing page adds 25 more tickets to the database. Pressing it 5 times results in 125+ tickets (25 seeded on startup + 5 x 25 simulated). The dashboard metrics become inflated and meaningless.

## Expected Behavior

The demo button should produce a clean, consistent demo experience every time it's pressed. A visitor pressing the button should always see a coherent set of results on the dashboard — not the accumulated debris of previous runs.

## Reproduction

1. Start the app (`dotnet run`)
2. Visit `/` and click "Run Demo" — redirects to `/dashboard` showing ~50 tickets (25 seed + 25 simulated)
3. Navigate back to `/` and click "Run Demo" again — dashboard now shows ~75 tickets
4. Repeat — ticket count grows unboundedly

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Pressing the demo button always produces a consistent, clean demo experience
- [ ] Dashboard metrics reflect only the current demo run, not accumulated history
- [ ] First visit after app startup behaves identically to subsequent demo runs
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix landing page stats: deflection rate is hardcoded instead of reflecting actual data
issues.body:
## Bug

The landing page specimen section displays "~70%" as the deflection rate. This value is hardcoded text — it doesn't reflect the actual deflection rate from processed tickets. After running the demo, the dashboard shows the real rate (which varies), but the landing page always says ~70% regardless.

The other stats (25 tickets/run, <2s processing) are also static, but the deflection rate is the most misleading because it claims to represent a measured outcome.

## Expected Behavior

The landing page stats should reflect real data. When the page loads, it should show the actual metrics from whatever tickets exist in the system. If no tickets have been processed yet, it's acceptable to show placeholder/zero state — but never fake numbers.

## Reproduction

1. Start the app
2. Landing page shows "~70%" deflection rate
3. Click "Run Demo" — dashboard shows actual rate (e.g., 68.0% or 72.0%)
4. Navigate back to `/` — still shows hardcoded "~70%"

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Landing page deflection rate reflects actual data from the system
- [ ] Stats update to reflect the current state of processed tickets
- [ ] Page handles the zero-ticket state gracefully (before any demo has run)
- [ ] Stats presentation still follows the Blueprint×Terminal instrument panel aesthetic
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix demo button: "executing..." state can hang indefinitely on slow or failed requests
issues.body:
## Bug

When the "Run Demo" button is clicked, it enters an "executing..." state with a spinner. If the API request takes a long time or the connection stalls, the button stays in this state indefinitely — the user has no way to cancel or retry. There's no timeout, no maximum wait, and no feedback about what's happening.

## Expected Behavior

The demo execution should have a reasonable timeout. If the request takes too long, the button should recover to a usable state with appropriate feedback. The user should never be stuck staring at "executing..." with no recourse.

## Reproduction

1. Visit `/`
2. Click "Run Demo"
3. If the server is slow or the network stalls, the button shows "executing..." forever
4. No way to retry without refreshing the page

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Demo button has a reasonable timeout for the API request
- [ ] If the request times out, the button recovers to a clickable state with feedback
- [ ] Error messaging tells the user something useful (not just a generic failure)
- [ ] Normal happy-path behavior unchanged (fast request → redirect to /dashboard)
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

issues.title: [Pipeline] Fix dashboard charts: doughnut charts are oversized and lack proper sizing constraints
issues.body:
## Bug

The two doughnut charts on the Dashboard page ("Distribution by Category" and "Distribution by Severity") are far too large. They dominate the page, pushing content below the fold and making the dashboard feel unbalanced. The charts expand to fill their containers without proper size constraints.

## Expected Behavior

The charts should be appropriately sized — large enough to read, small enough to coexist with the metrics panels above them as part of a single dashboard view. The dashboard should feel like a mission control panel where all key information is visible at once, not a page you have to scroll through because two pie charts consumed all the vertical space.

The chart styling should also feel consistent with the Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic — the current default Chart.js rendering looks generic against the themed background.

## Reproduction

1. Run the demo and visit `/dashboard`
2. Scroll down past the metrics panels
3. The two doughnut charts are massive — each takes up most of the viewport height

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Charts are reasonably sized — dashboard metrics and charts visible together without excessive scrolling
- [ ] Charts maintain proper aspect ratio across screen sizes
- [ ] Chart styling is consistent with the Blueprint×Terminal aesthetic (colors, borders, legend styling)
- [ ] Charts still render correctly with real data from `/api/metrics/overview`
- [ ] Page remains responsive on mobile and desktop
- [ ] `dotnet build TicketDeflection.sln` succeeds
- [ ] `dotnet test TicketDeflection.sln` passes
- [ ] No `.github/workflows/` files modified

pull_requests.title: [Pipeline] Ticket Classification Service & Classify Endpoint
pull_requests.body:
Closes #128

## Changes

Implements the Ticket Classification Service with keyword-based rules and a classify endpoint.

### Files Added
- **`TicketDeflection/Services/ClassificationService.cs`** — `ClassifyTicket(Ticket ticket)` method that classifies tickets using 15+ keyword rules across 4 categories (case-insensitive match against title + description), sets `Severity` based on category, and sets `Status = Classified`
- **`TicketDeflection/DTOs/TicketDtos.cs`** — `TicketResponse`, `CreateTicketRequest`, `UpdateTicketRequest` records
- **`TicketDeflection/Endpoints/ClassifyEndpoints.cs`** — `POST /api/tickets/{id}/classify` endpoint: looks up ticket, classifies it, persists, returns 200 with `TicketResponse` or 404 if not found
- **`TicketDeflection.Tests/ClassificationServiceTests.cs`** — 7 unit tests: crash→Bug/High, how-do-I→HowTo/Low, no-match→Other/Medium, error keyword, account keyword, feature request keyword, case-insensitive matching
- **`TicketDeflection.Tests/ClassifyEndpointTests.cs`** — 2 integration tests: classify existing ticket returns 200 with correct category/severity/status, non-existent ticket returns 404

### Modified
- **`TicketDeflection/Program.cs`** — registers `ClassificationService` as scoped (below `// --- Service Registrations ---`), maps classify endpoint (below `// --- Endpoint Mappings ---`)

### Keyword Rules
| Keywords | Category | Severity |
|---------|----------|---------|
| crash, error, broken, bug, exception | Bug | High |
| how do i, how to, help with, guide | HowTo | Low |
| add feature, request, wish, would be nice | FeatureRequest | Medium |
| login, password, account, billing, subscription | AccountIssue | Medium |
| _(no match)_ | Other | Medium |

> **Note**: `TicketDtos.cs` is also added in PR #141 (Ticket CRUD Endpoints). If both PRs merge, a minor conflict will need resolution — keeping all three DTOs from both PRs is correct.
